hints_html:
The acceleration \(a(t)\) is the second derivative \(a(t)=x''(t)\) of the position \(x(t)\).

With \(a(t)=x''(t)\) we find, that we need to solve the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} x''(t)&=\cos(t),\\ x'(0)&=0 \quad\text{(the molecule rests at time 0)}\\ x(0)&=1\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
The acceleration $a(t)$ is the second derivative $a(t)=x''(t)$ of the
position $x(t)$.

With $a(t)=x''(t)$ we find, that we need to solve the differential
equation

\begin{align*}
x''(t)&=\cos(t),\\
x'(0)&=0 \quad\text{(the molecule rests at time 0)}\\
x(0)&=1
\end{align*}
hints_raw:
The acceleration <math> a(t)\ </math> is the second derivative <math>\ a(t)=x''(t)</math> of the position <math>\ x(t)</math>.
With <math>\ a(t)=x''(t)</math> we find, that we need to solve the differential equation

<math>\begin{align}
x''(t)&=\cos(t),\\
x'(0)&=0 \quad\text{(the molecule rests at time 0)}\\
x(0)&=1
\end{align}</math>
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
We find, that we need to solve the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} x''(t)&=\cos(t)\\ x'(0)&=0\\ x(0)&=1\end{aligned}\]

We integrate \(x''(t)=\cos(t)\) and get \(x'(t)=\sin(t)+c_1\). With \(0= x'(0)=\sin(0)+c_1=c_1\) we find \(c_1=0\).

We continue with integrating \(x'(t)=\sin(t)\), which leads to \(x(t)=-\cos(t)+c_2\). With \(x(0)=1\) we find \(1=x(0)=-\cos(0)+c_2=-1+c_2\) and get \(c_2=2\).

The velocity beeing \(x'(t)=\sin(t)\) reaches \(-1\) at \(t=\frac{3}{2}\pi\), and we get

\(x\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) = -\cos\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) + 2 = -0+2=2\).

So, the answer is (d).
sols_latex:
We find, that we need to solve the differential equation

\begin{align*}
x''(t)&=\cos(t)\\
x'(0)&=0\\
x(0)&=1
\end{align*}

We integrate $x''(t)=\cos(t)$ and get $x'(t)=\sin(t)+c_1$. With
$0= x'(0)=\sin(0)+c_1=c_1$ we find $c_1=0$.

We continue with integrating $x'(t)=\sin(t)$, which leads to
$x(t)=-\cos(t)+c_2$. With $x(0)=1$ we find $1=x(0)=-\cos(0)+c_2=-1+c_2$
and get $c_2=2$.

The velocity beeing $x'(t)=\sin(t)$ reaches $-1$ at $t=\frac{3}{2}\pi$,
and we get

$x\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) = -\cos\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) + 2 = -0+2=2$.

\textbf{So, the answer is (d).}
sols_raw:
We find, that we need to solve the differential equation

<math>\begin{align}
x''(t)&=\cos(t)\\
x'(0)&=0\\
x(0)&=1
\end{align}</math>

We integrate <math> \ x''(t)=\cos(t)</math> and get <math> x'(t)=\sin(t)+c_1\ </math>.
With <math>0= x'(0)=\sin(0)+c_1=c_1\ </math> we find <math> c_1=0\ </math>.

We continue with integrating <math>x'(t)=\sin(t)\ </math>, which leads to <math>\ x(t)=-\cos(t)+c_2</math>.
With <math>\ x(0)=1</math> we find <math>\ 1=x(0)=-\cos(0)+c_2=-1+c_2</math> and get <math>\ c_2=2</math>.

The velocity beeing <math>\ x'(t)=\sin(t)</math> reaches <math> \ -1</math> at <math> t=\frac{3}{2}\pi\ </math>, and we get

<math>\ x\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) = -\cos\left(\frac{3}{2}\pi\right) + 2 = -0+2=2</math>.

'''So, the answer is (d).'''
statement_html:
Multiple Choice question: Select ONE correct answer. You will not be graded for any work.

A charged molecule moves in a changing electric field which results in an acceleration of a(t) = cos(t) (in appropriate units). At time t = 0, the molecule is at rest at position x(0) = 1. What is the position x(t) when the molecule’s velocity reaches the value -1 for the first time after time 0?

(a) -1

(b) 0

(c) 1

(d) 2

(e) The velocity never reaches -1
statement_latex:
\emph{Multiple Choice question: Select ONE correct answer. You will not
be graded for any work.}

A charged molecule moves in a changing electric field which results in
an acceleration of \emph{a(t) = cos(t)} (in appropriate units). At time
\emph{t = 0}, the molecule is at rest at position \emph{x(0) = 1}. What
is the position \emph{x(t)} when the molecule's velocity reaches the
value -1 for the first time after time 0?

(a) -1

(b) 0

(c) 1

(d) 2

(e) The velocity never reaches -1
statement_raw:

(d) 2
